sen.j: 宗峰妙超（しゅうほう みょうちょう、弘安5年(1282年) - 延元2年/建武 (日本)4年12月22日 (旧暦)(1338年1月13日)）は、鎌倉時代末期の臨済宗の僧。
sen.e: Myocho SHUHO (1282-January 13, 1338) was a priest of Rinzai Sect who was active in the last Kamakura Period.

sen.j: 建武4年(1337年)、妙超は病に伏し重態となるが、花園法皇の求めに応じて、妙超没後に花園法皇が師とすべき禅僧として、弟子の関山慧玄を推挙した。
sen.e: When Myocho became seriously ill in 1337, he recommended, upon the request of the Abdicated Emperor Hanazono, Egen KANZAN as the Zen priest who was to be the mentor of the Abdicated Emperor Hanazono after his death.

sen.j: 師の南浦紹明（大応国師）から宗峰妙超（大灯国師）を経て関山慧玄へ続く法系を「応灯関」といい、現在、日本臨済宗はみなこの法系に属する。
sen.e: Zen system developed by Jomin NANPO (Daio Kokushi), Myocho's mentor, Myocho SHUHO (Daito Kokushi) and Egen KANZAN is called "otokan" and all of current Rinzai Sects in Japan belong to this system.

The Zen system developed by Jomin NANPO (Daio Kokushi), Myocho's mentor, Myocho SHUHO (Daito Kokushi) and Egen KANZAN is called "otokan" and all of the current Rinzai Sects in Japan belong to this system.

The Buddhist lineage from Jomin NANPO (Daio Kokushi), Myocho's mentor, through Myocho SHUHO (Daito Kokushi) to Egen KANZAN is called 'otokan' (literally means Daio, Daito and Kanzen) which all of the current Rinzai Sects in Japan belong to.
